Self imposed costly deadline - effective
Try and enjoy the process of achieving something - instead of only 20 more minutes of torture try and think I enjoy being productive or I'm doing something great.
Make a list of the reasons you want to complete the goal.
Remove the temptations, put obstacles in their way.

Suggested solutions in the video :
1) Use Pomodoro Technique
25 min work --- 5 min break + reward (like snacks or games) --- Repeat (Gradually increase work duration).
2) Create deadlines (External deadlines work more effectively than the deadlines created by yourself).
3) Enjoy the process of being productive "This is great"
4) Make a list of reasons why you want to do the work (Good grades? Money? Free weekend?)
5) Remove temptations (such as Instagram, Reddit or other social platforms, uninstall games, or whatever distract you)

I think we procrastinate because there is a due date for pretty much anything:When the homework is due, when your bills are due, when the new movie comes out, when, when, when. Our brains are not used to prepare before an event.
Back in the prehistoric days, there were no 'due dates'. Our bodies naturally tells us what we should do now: I'm hungry, I'm bored, I'm cold, etc.

TLDR We're not used to be doing certain things based on what time it is.

My dad has some theories on procrastination: First, it's mostly habit. So, choose a habit to change (e.g. getting up by at least 9am every morning) and stick to it religiously. After about 3 weeks, it's become habit, and you can move on to the next habit to kick.

The key is to not choose 10 habits to kick at the same time. You'll get overwhelmed and discouraged when you miss one, and then kick the entire concept.

My personal tip in addition to the above: When I'm on a study break and am starting in on a YouTube marathon despite saying ONLY TWO VIDEOS, get up and walk down the stairs. Where you go isn't important; you're just breaking the mind-set that you're in so that when you return, you can re-focus.

Cheers,

As implied in the beginning of the video, procrastination is a special case of a more general phenomenon called Akrasia. In addition to irrationally avoiding things you don't feel like doing at the moment, hyperbolic discounting also leads you to do things now that you *should* delay. Overeating is a classic example. The science is the same. I like the suggestion of creating obstacles to procrastination. For the really big guns: StickK or the more data-oriented Beeminder.

Absolutely! We didn't mean to suggest that this system is intrinsically bad or wrong. But simply, that it exists, and as a by product it can lead to procrastination (and other issues). Clearly this trait had an evolutionary advantage, and temporal discounting is good for all of the reasons you mentioned. But an advantage in one direction, can sometimes lead to a deficiency in another. This is often called an evolutionary trade-off.

I followed this when I was in college.  When I was first learning computer programming I did a few things to help me focus.  First, I closed all web browsers (No FB).  Going one step further I  closed all open programs that weren't related to what I was doing.  Step two (or three), I either listened to no music at all or only music with no words.  This proved the be the biggest factor.  Because of this I collected a very large library of Video Game, Movie, and Symphonic soundtracks. =)

It's because of the way your lips form for the next sound. B, P and M have the same lip formation, and you change the n sound to an m sound to let it "flow" better.
Imbalance, Imbecile
Impossible, Impenetrable
Immaculate, Immaterial
Similar to how you add an "n" to "a" when the next sound is a vowel sound.
